New Delhi

New Delhi, Feb. 3 -- The Supreme Court will hear on February 8 a petition by US retail giant Amazon against a Delhi high court order which stayed the ongoing arbitration proceedings against Future Group related to a deal between the two companies in 2019.

The plea was mentioned before a bench headed by Chief Justice of India (CJI) NV Ramana by senior advocate Gopal Subramanium on behalf of Amazon.

"We are here against the Delhi high court's division bench order where the arbitral tribunal proceeding was injuncted... Because of the impugned order, arbitral tribunal proceeding are not going on," he said.

"List next Tuesday," the CJI, sitting with justices AS Bopanna and Hima Kohli on the bench, replied.

In December, the Competition Commission of India (CCI) suspended the clearance for the 2019 deal between Amazon and Future, saying that Amazon failed to notify it about certain crucial details of its acquisition as required under the law. CCI also imposed a penalty of Rs.202 crore on Amazon.

Based on the Competition Commission of India order, Future moved the Delhi high court seeking stay on the ongoing arbitration proceedings before the Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC)'s Delhi-seated tribunal.

While Future's plea was rejected by a single-judge bench, a division bench on January 5 stayed the proceedings before the tribunal, citing the CCI order as one of the reasons for doing so.

It added that irreparable loss would be caused to Future if proceedings are not stayed. The division bench was expected to hear the case on February 1 but it got adjourned to March 21 due to unavailability of the bench.

Needs a stock graf on the fight in the retail space and the long saga that has gone to multiple courts, arbitrators and commissions.

On Tuesday, the top court set aside two adverse orders by the Delhi high court passed in February and March 2021 against the Future Group at the instance of Amazon over the former's proposed $3.4 billion sale of retail assets to Reliance.

The Chief Justice of India-led bench held that coercive orders on attachment of properties of Kishore Biyani and other promoters of Future were passed by the high court without giving sufficient opportunity to them, and that there was no wilful disobedience on the part of the group's companies.

In a setback for Amazon, the bench further referred the matter back to the single-judge bench in the Delhi high court to reconsider all issues afresh and deliver a judgment on the enforceability of the arbitral awards and other orders passed by the Singapore International Arbitration Centre.
